title: UST eyes lead and revenge
text:
by Christian Jacinto
October 17, 2015 Games Today
(Mall of Asia Arena)
2 p.m. – Ateneo vs Adamson
4 p.m. – UST vs NU
University of Santo Tomas hopes to hit two birds with one stone when it plays defending champion National University today in the UAAP basketball tournament at the Mall of Asia Arena.
The Tigers are seeking not only to rejoin the Far Eastern University Tamaraws for the lead but also to avenge their 55-54 loss to the Bulldogs during the first round.
Jose Rizal University’s Tey Teodoro tries to score against Mapua’s Allwell Oraeme during their NCAA playoff match yesterday at the Mall of Asia Arena. The game is being played at presstime. (Bob Dungo Jr.)
Game time is at 4 p.m.
But going up against the Bulldogs, UST coach Bong de la Cruz hopes his squad will execute a new tack, which is to start strong and not fall behind early, as was the case in some of their past games where they had to produce strong finishing kicks to beat their rivals.
The latest example was against the La Salle Green Archers last Sunday where they had to storm back from an 11-point deficit before winning, 81-79.
“Sana next game hindi na kami come-from-behind. Kung lalamang kami sana diretso na,” said De la Cruz, who definitely has vengeance in mind against the Bulldogs.
One guy still hurting from that loss is UST center Karim Abdul, who was outplayed by his foreign counterpart Alfred Aroga in the fourth period.
Aroga capped off his dominance of Abdul when he knocked down a fade away jumper in the dying seconds that allowed NU to steal the victory.
“That shot hurt me so much. I’m gonna make sure he doesn’t do that again. I’m gonna correct my mistakes and I’m gonna get myself ready this week,” Abdul said.
Meanwhile, Ateneo is favored to beat lowly Adamson in the 2 p.m. opener and tighten its grip on the top four.
A victory will put the Blue Eagles in a tie for third with the Green Archers.
In beach volleyball, defending women’s champion UST dealt favored Ateneo a second straight loss as Cherry Rondina and Rica Rivera turned back Alyssa Valdez and Bea Tan, 21-18, 21-18, yesterday at the Sands SM By The Bay.
Reigning MVP Rondina and Rivera were impressive with their well-placed shots and defense to help the Tigresses book their third straight win.
The setback put a dent to the title bid of the Lady Eagles, who opened the tournament with four consecutive wins, of advancing to the Final Four.
Ateneo dropped to 4-2 in a tie with UST and La Salle, a 26-24, 21-13 winner over NU, from third to fifth spots.
